patents.description: The invention provides methods for producing crystalline an anti- PD-1 monoclonal antibody (mAb), wherein the mAb is pembrolizumab or a pembrolizumab variant, comprising (1) mixing a solution comprising (a) the mAb, (b) polyethylene glycol (PEG), and (c) an additive selected from the group consisting of: caffeine, theophylline, 2' deoxyguanosine-5'-monophosphate, a bioactive gibberellin, and a pharmaceutically acceptable salt of said bioactive gibberellin, to form a crystallization solution, (2) incubating the crystallization solution for a period of time sufficient for crystal formation; and (3) optionally harvesting the crystalline anti-PD-1 mAb from the solution. In specific embodiments, the PEG is PEG 3350 and the additive is caffeine. The invention also relates to the novel anti-human PD-1 mAb crystals produced by the methods described herein. Characterization of re-dissolved crystalline suspensions using several biochemical methods showed the bio-physical properties of the re-dissolved mAb crystals were consistent with the intact antibody starting sample. The crystals and methods of the invention are amenable to multiple pharmaceutical applications such as purification, storage, formulation, and drug delivery.
patents.title: Anti-human PD-1 Antibody (Pembrolizumab) Crystals and Methods of Use Thereof

patents.description: The present disclosure provides novel anhydrate crystalline Forms 1 and 4 of 4'- Ethynyl-2-fluoro-2'-deoxyadenosine and pharmaceutical compositions thereof, each of which may be useful for the inhibition of HIV reverse transcriptase, the treatment or prophylaxis of HIV infection and/or the treatment, prophylaxis and/or delay in the onset or progression of AIDS or ARC.
patents.title: Novel Crystalline Forms of an NRTTI Compound

patents.description: The invention relates to stable formulations of antibodies against human programmed death receptor PD-1, or antigen binding fragments thereof and a PH20 variant or fragment thereof. The invention further provides methods for treating various cancers with formulations of the invention. In some embodiments of the methods of the invention, the formulations are administered to a subject by subcutaneous administration.
patents.title: Stable Formulations of Programmed Death Receptor 1 (PD-1) Antibodies (Pembrolizumab) and Hyaluronidase Variants and Fragments Thereof and Methods of Use Thereof

patents.description: In some embodiments, a reciprocal injection device includes a platform having a motor, a gearbox operatively coupled to the motor, an actuation slide driven by the motor, a pair of clamp fixtures for supporting two syringes, a pair of axially translatable syringe plunger fixtures, and an interface in communication with the platform and configured and arranged to actuate the motor.
patents.title: Reciprocal injection device and methods of using same

ingestedContentSummary.description: Phosphate buffers are crucial for cryopreservative stability in pharmaceuticals, food processing, biomedical sciences, and biology. However, their freeze concentrates lack quantitative characterization, especially regarding the physicochemical...
ingestedContentSummary.title: Probing Chemical Equilibrium in Frozen Sodium Phosphate Buffer Solution by 31P Solid-State NMR

message.text:
Excited to share our recent publication in the Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters! We explored the chemical equilibrium in sodium phosphate buffer upon freezing, quantifying all phosphate species in the freeze concentrate. Our findings show a nearly 40-fold increase in ionic strength in ~1% of mobile water, and observe spectroscopically the amorphous state of trehalose eliminating buffer salt crystallization.

Kudos to Yong Du at Merck and Jinghan Li at University of Minnesota, and thanks to Prof. Raj Suryanarayanan for another great collaboration on the in-depth physicochemical study of pharmaceutical frozen solutions. We deeply appreciate the efforts and scientific insights from Editors and reviewers.
https://lnkd.in/eNkwqB_j

Adding one example to the community efforts on analyzing biologics non-invasively in primary containers and in situ without dilution. A fantastic collaboration between Merck and University of Maryland - kudos to the team for this innovative work Jing Song, Mark Taraban, Bruce Yu, Lynn Lu, Pallavi Guha Biswas, Wei Xu, Hanmi Xi, Akhilesh Bhambhani, Guangli Hu, PhD

Assessing the Stability of the marketed mAb drug Dupixent® using wNMR
https://lnkd.in/eFSWeRHh

It's exciting that Bruker BioSpin featured our biophysical study on lipid nanoparticle (#LNP)! This innovative application of solution NMR and solid-state NMR provides a way to quantitatively probe the internal structure of LNP-based vaccines and therapeutics.

Kudos to the Merck team: Ryan Schroder, Phillip Dorsey, Joe Vanderburgh, Wei Xu, Suzanne M. D'Addio, Lee Klein, and Marian Gindy.

ingestedContentSummary.title: Probing Molecular Packing of Lipid Nanoparticles from 31P Solution and Solid-State NMR

message.text:
Interested in adding an atomic resolution approach to your analytical workflow for LNP characterization? Within this study, scientists from Merck & Co introduce 31P nuclear magnetic resonance (#NMR) methods to acquire structural and dynamic information about the phospholipid envelope of LNPs. Specifically, it demonstrates that the 31P chemical shift anisotropy (CSA) parameters serve as a sensitive indicator of the molecular assembly of distearoylphosphatidylcholine (DSPC) lipids within the particles. An analytical protocol for measuring 31P CSA is developed, which can be implemented using either solution NMR or solid-state NMR, offering wide accessibility and adaptability.

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/d2H9Nghb

ACS Publications 

#Pharma #ssNMR

commentary.text: Excellent work on benchtop qNMR Ciarán C. Lynch, Ph.D. Gennady Khirich and Ryan Lee Merck team!

Thank you, Kate and Bruker BioSpin, for sharing our work! A huge shoutout and congratulations to the co-first authors, Yong Du and Jinghan Li! Collaborating with Prof. Suryanarayanan, University of Minnesota has been an absolute pleasure and learning experience.

Tons of good science from colleagues in the #biologics and #lyo communities have offered us invaluable insights into the physiochemical understanding of pharmaceutical frozen solutions. Thank you, all!
Thank you, Anna, your team, and Bruker BioSpin, for kindly highlighting our research. Great to see these pharmaceutical studies from our communities!
Looking forward to it, Tapan Das!
Congratulations, Mingyue! Well deserved and very exciting!
